TEXT: CARDINAL . NORP The applicant , Mr PERSON , is a NORP national , who was born in DATE and lives in GPE . He was represented before the Court by PERSON , a lawyer practising in GPE .
CARDINAL . ORG ( “ the Government ” ) were represented by their Agent , PERSON , of ORG .
CARDINAL . The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .
CARDINAL . At the relevant time the applicant was a practising lawyer and a member of ORG ( “ the KBA ” ) .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG , relying on section CARDINAL ) of LAW DATE ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) , decided to suspend the applicant ’s membership because a charge had been brought against him for aggravated hooliganism , an offence under LAW of DATE .
CARDINAL . The applicant submitted that on CARDINAL occasion he was prevented from defending a client in proceedings before the domestic courts because of the suspension .

CARDINAL . The applicant appealed against his suspension to ORG . He argued , most notably , that the measure had breached the presumption of innocence and his constitutionally - guaranteed right to work .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG upheld the ORG ’s decision .

CARDINAL . Upon further appeal by the applicant , who reiterated the above - mentioned arguments , by a judgment of CARDINAL DATE ORG quashed the applicant ’s suspension , noting that as of DATE ORG had repealed the relevant part of section CARDINAL ) of LAW as being contrary to LAW . ORG also noted that the legal power to suspend an individual from exercising professional activities pending the outcome of criminal proceedings against him was regulated by LAW ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) , which was the constitutionally sound way to achieve the aim pursued by that measure .

CARDINAL . Meanwhile , on CARDINAL DATE ORG notified the applicant that following the repeal of the relevant part of section PERSON ) of LAW he was again eligible to practise his profession . On DATE ORG formally revoked its decision of DATE .

CARDINAL . DATE and DATE the applicant was convicted on CARDINAL occasions of a variety of offences , such as theft , hooliganism , making false accusations and perjury , most of which were committed DATE . As of DATE there were other criminal proceedings pending against him .

CARDINAL . NORP In particular , in the criminal proceedings which led to the applicant ’s suspension from the GPE , by a judgment of CARDINAL DATE , in force as of DATE , GPE convicted the applicant of aggravated hooliganism and sentenced him to DATE imprisonment .

CARDINAL . On several occasions in DATE the applicant was remanded in custody in connection with the criminal proceedings against him . He was imprisoned in FAC from DATE to CARDINAL DATE to serve an aggregate prison sentence in respect of a number of his convictions .
CARDINAL . On the basis of the applicant ’s convictions , on CARDINAL DATE the ORG struck him off the list of its members .

CARDINAL . Section PERSON ) of LAW DATE as originally enacted provided that barristers’ practising rights were to be temporarily suspended in the event , inter alia , that they were charged with a criminal offence .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG , acting on the initiative of a group of its members , repealed that part of section PERSON ) . The members of ORG who initiated the amendment argued that suspension while criminal charges were pending was contrary to the LAW , which provided that everyone was innocent until proved guilty , and that the right to practise a profession was guaranteed and protected by law . The repeal entered into force on DATE .

CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL of the Code of Criminal Procedure DATE , in force until DATE , provided that in the event that criminal charges were brought for an offence which related to the accused individual ’s professional activity , and where the accused ’s professional position could prevent the establishment of the facts , the first - instance court could , upon the prosecutor ’s request , suspend the individual from his position . The measure was to be discontinued when it was no longer considered justified .
